Award.AwardTitle: Engineering Design Process Portfolio Scoring Rubric (EDPPSR)

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Education and Human Resources

Award.AbstractNarration:
Currently there are numerous opportunities for students to participate in design-based experiences organized by local schools and clubs, government laboratories and national organizations. While these programs can inspire students' interest in STEM, there are no commonly accepted frameworks to benchmark learning and instruction in order to study students' growth in STEM knowledge and skills or their self-efficacy and persistence to pursue STEM or to recognize their achievements based on common measures.

The purpose of this proposal, "Engineering Design Process Portfolio Scoring Rubric (EDPPSR)" is to test the efficacy of the EDPPSR scoring system that could be applied to differentiate levels of performance in the domain of the engineering design based projects. The intent of the study is to determine the reliability and validity of the EDPPSR across student work produced in diverse contexts (formal versus informal, low versus high stakes, high school versus college) and under different conditions (individual versus group work, self-initiated versus assigned, etc.). The proposed study is a critical step in the scale-up of a validated and reliable scoring tool that could be used to evaluate design-based projects and to inform instructional practice. Specifically, the EDPPSR is proposed as the format for a future engineering advanced placement exam.
The research questions which will guide the project are:
1. Which types of artifacts provided as portfolio entries may constitute evidence of proficiency in each ESPPSR element?
2. How will artifact types be likely to differ within/across diverse contexts and conditions?
3. Do the rubric criteria address any content extraneous to the engineering design process or are any irrelevant to the construct?
4. Do criteria accurately and fully address all elements of the engineering design process?

A validated and reliable ESPPSR could potentially lead to students gaining admission, recognition or even undergraduate placement credit for their project-based activities and could impact the recruitment of talented students into the STEM pipeline and could inform the recruitment of students from under-represented groups.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Design is notoriously difficult to practice in traditional classrooms, school day schedules, and across disciplines. Increasingly, authentic opportunities are being made available for teachers to gain the competencies to learn and practice design across both formal and informal settings; and prepare their students for the 21st century workforce.  At the same time, the traditional classroom-based training and professional development of teachers is being transformed by online and hybrid learning technologies. 

The National Science Foundations (NSF) PRIME program provided our University of Maryland at College Park (UMCP) based team the resources to not only formalize a partnership between the College of Education (COE) and the School of Engineering (SOE), but also to collaborate with consultants and other researchers on the development of a rubric for the design process, the Engineering Design Process Portfolio Scoring Rubric (EDPPSR).

The EDPPSR can be used as tool and as a reference to address the emerging and growing need to prepare teachers and instructors to introduce and practice design with their students. The EDPPSR has been used by both high school and unviersity students in their classrooms, as well as in informal competitions.

The EDPPSR is the guiding framework for the Project Lead the Way (PLTW) e-portfolio, www.innovationportal.org. The Innovation Portal has over 60,000 current users. Teachers across the United States have been trained by PLTW to use and apply the EDPPSR. These teachers have used the EDPPSR in their PLTW classrooms.

In addition, as illustrated in the images provided with this summary, the EDPPSR is also the guiding framework for the mobile Learning Management System (LMS), MyDesign®. As an LMS, MyDesign® aligns to the EDPPSR as it guides a user (teachers and students) through the design process. Each step or action taken by the user can be recorded and mapped to the EDPPSR. Thus providing information and data on a continuous basis, from the conceptualization of the design through to the various iterations. Like the PLTW Innovation Portfolio,  MyDesign® is a portfolio of a users designs across classrooms, grade levels, and program (e.g. competitions).
